awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Alisa Knizel is "Integrable Probability." The host institution for the fellowship is Columbia University, and the sponsoring scientist is Ivan Corwin.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The PI's research focuses on the interplay between probabilistic and algebro-geometric properties of lattice models in statistical mechanics. These models can be used to study complex random systems, such as traffic models, growth models (i.e. disease spreading) and many others. The systems under consideration usually have one or more parameters, e.g. the number of particles or the temperature, and the point of interest is the study of their behavior as these parameters tend to an appropriate limit.
The supported research had three main directions: the study of log-gases (ensembles of particles on the line, confined by an external potential, that repel each other logarithmically), traffic models and random tilings of bounded lattice regions. The PI with co-authors developed new methods to analyze these systems and computed their important characteristics.The fellowship supported four publications and two preprints.


Broader impacts: Tha accomplished research has strong ties with physics and many research directions were motivated by it.

At Columbia the PI served as the faculty advisor for the Barnard and Columbia Chapter of the Association for Women in Mathematics, helping to organize a mentoring program for faculty and graduate students to meet with female undergraduate math majors.  Every year the PI served as a mentor for this program. Mentors discuss with their mentees math problems, their curriculum, and the challenges of academic and industry careers. For those who choose to pursue graduate school in mathematics, mentor offers help and advice on the application process. In 2020 Columbia University AWM student chapter was selected as the winner of the AWM Student Chapter Award for Scientific Excellence. In addition, the PI helped Prof. Ivan Corwin to mentor a graduate student and a high school student.


 A huge part of a mathematician's experience is the community, and throughout her career the PI has been willing to take on various administrative responsibilities to make it a rich and fulfilling one. During the last year of the fellowship PI was in charge of scheduling and inviting speakers for the Probability Seminar at Columbia, she also co-organized the Columbia/Courant joint Probability Seminar (an annual one day workshop) for the previous two years. During her fellowship PI has given numerous talks on her research in North America, Europe and Australia.


Last Modified: 07/07/2022
Modified by: Alisa Knizel
